security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no executable code. Uses standard MCP tools (Read, Glob, Grep, Bash, Write) for their documented purpose of analyzing git history and generating documentation.

content.user_title: Generate release notes from git commits
content.value_statement: Developers spend hours manually converting git commits into readable release notes. This skill automatically analyzes commit history, groups changes by type, and formats them into user-friendly release documentation.
actual_capabilities: Extract commits from git history using tags or date ranges
Categorize commits by type (features, fixes, performance, breaking changes)
Convert technical commit messages into user-friendly descriptions
Generate CHANGELOG.md or GitHub Release Notes format
Highlight breaking changes with migration guidance
limitations: Requires conventional commit messages for best categorization results
Cannot generate meaningful output without git repository access
User descriptions depend on commit message quality and detail
Breaking changes detection requires BREAKING: prefix in commits

use_cases.title: Release preparation
use_cases.description: Quickly generate release notes before deploying new versions to production

use_cases.title: Community communication
use_cases.description: Create clear changelogs that help users understand what is new and what changed

use_cases.title: CI/CD automation
use_cases.description: Automatically generate release notes as part of continuous deployment workflows

prompt_templates.title: Basic release notes
prompt_templates.scenario: Generate release notes for a version
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate release notes for the latest version. Use git log to get commits since the last tag, categorize them, and create a user-friendly changelog.

prompt_templates.title: Date range summary
prompt_templates.scenario: Summarize changes in a time period
prompt_templates.prompt: Summarize all commits from last week. Group by type (features, fixes, breaking changes) and write in user-friendly language.

prompt_templates.title: Breaking changes focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Show all breaking changes since v1.0. Include migration steps for users upgrading from the previous version.

prompt_templates.title: Contributor attribution
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate release notes with contributor attribution. Include all commits and mention contributors by username.

output: - Automatic token refresh keeps users logged in longer
- New dashboard with real-time analytics display
- Bulk export functionality for data reports
- Fixed intermittent errors during order processing
- Resolved login timeout issues on mobile devices
- Faster database queries for large datasets

best_practices: Use conventional commit format (feat:, fix:, BREAKING:) for automatic categorization
Write commit messages from the user perspective, not developer implementation details
Highlight breaking changes clearly with migration guidance for users
Mention contributors to recognize team members in release notes
anti_patterns: Using vague commit messages like 'fix stuff' or 'update code'
Skipping the BREAKING: prefix for compatibility-breaking changes
Including internal technical details that do not help users
Forgetting to verify the git history before generating release notes

faq.question: What git commands does this skill use?
faq.answer: Uses git log with tags, date ranges, and pretty formatting to extract commit history for analysis.

faq.question: How many commits can it process?
faq.answer: No strict limit, but best results with under 500 commits. Large histories work better with date ranges.

faq.question: Can it integrate with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, works with GitHub Actions and other CI systems using git log in workflow scripts.

faq.question: Is my git data stored or sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No, all processing happens locally using standard MCP tools. No data leaves your environment.

faq.question: What if commits do not follow conventional format?
faq.answer:: Commits without prefixes fall into an uncategorized section. Quality depends on commit message clarity.

faq.question: How does this compare to auto-changelog tools?
faq.answer: This skill adds AI-powered language transformation, converting technical terms into user-friendly descriptions.
